GeneralExplanationGrp.MediumExplanationTxt: GRANT APPLICATION SUBMISSION INFORMATION(A) THE FOUNDATION DID NOT ACCEPT UNSOLICITED INQUIRIES IN 2018 EXCEPT FOR APPLICANTS TO THE BELLAGIO CENTER, ITALY.(B) APPLICANTS TO THE BELLAGIO CENTER,ITALY, ARE ASKED TO APPLY ON LINE AT WWW.ROCKEFELLERFOUNDATION.ORG.(C) IN 2018, THERE WERE NO SPECIFIC SUBMISSION DEADLINES FOR THEFOUNDATION'S PROGRAMS, OTHER THAN FOR THE BELLAGIO PROGRAM. INADDITION, FROM TIME TO TIME, REQUESTS FOR PROPOSALS WERE SENT OUT WITHSPECIFIC DEADLINES TO A SELECT GROUP OF PROSPECTIVE GRANTEES FORPARTICULAR PROJECTS.(D) THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION DEVELOPS ITS PROGRAMS, STRATEGIES ANDAPPROACHES DESIGNED TO HAVE AN IMPACT ON A PARTICULAR SET OF ISSUES ORCHALLENGES THROUGH A CONSULTATIVE AND COLLABORATIVE PROCESS. WE ENGAGE A VARIETY OF GROUPS, INCLUDING SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS, POLICYMAKERS AND REPRESENTATIVES OF APPLICABLE COMMUNITIES TO FULLY UNDERSTAND A GIVEN CHALLENGE OR OPPORTUNITY, INCLUDING THE ECONOMIC, POLITICAL OR SOCIAL CONTEXT IN WHICH IT RESIDES. IN THE COURSE OF PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT, THE FOUNDATION IDENTIFIES AND CONSIDERS ORGANIZATIONS THAT WE BELIEVE ARE BEST POSITIONED TO IMPLEMENT DEFINED COMPONENTS OF A PROGRAM. THIS PROCESS HELPS DETERMINE THE ORGANIZATIONS TO WHICH THE FOUNDATION WILL PROVIDE GRANTS, AND WE WILL THEN REQUEST PROJECT PROPOSALS FROM THOSE ORGANIZATIONS. IN ORDER TO FOCUS AND MAXIMIZE THE IMPACT OF OUR GRANTMAKING, WE RARELY PROVIDE FUNDING IN RESPONSE TO UNSOLICITED PROPOSALS. AS A MATTER OF POLICY, THE FOUNDATION DOES NOT GIVE OR LEND MONEY FOR PERSONAL AID TO INDIVIDUALS OR, EXCEPT IN RARE CASES, FUND ENDOWMENTS, OR CONTRIBUTE TO BUILDING AND OPERATING FUNDS.DURING 2018, THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION PURSUED ITS1913 MISSION OF PROMOTING THE WELL-BEING OF HUMANITY THROUGHOUT THEWORLD BY BUILDING COLLABORTIVE RELATIONSHIPS WITH PARTNERS AND GRANTEES TO SOLVE GLOBAL CHALLENGES RELATED TO HEALTH, FOOD, POWER AND ECONOMIC MOBILITY. CURRENT WORK WITHIN THESE INITIATIVES, AS WELL AS AREAS BEING EXPLORED FOR FUTURE INITIATIVES, ARE DESCRIBED ON THE FOUNDATION'S WEB SITE AT WWW.ROCKEFELLERFOUNDATION.ORG, WHICH IS CONTINUALLY UPDATED. ACTIVE WORK DURING 2018 INCLUDED: 100 RESILIENT CITIES; THE ALLIANCE FOR A GREEN REVOLUTION IN AFRICA; SMART POWER FOR RURAL DEVELOPMENT; INNOVATIVE FINANCE; AND CO-IMPACT.THE FOUNDATION ALSO OPERATES A CONFERENCE AND STUDY PROGRAM AT ITSBELLAGIO CENTER IN ITALY.

THE FOLLOWING TEXT RELATES TO THE STATEMENT 20, THE EXPENDITURE RESPONSIBILITY STATEMENT, IN RESPONSE TO PART VII-B, LINE 5C.PROSPECTIVE GRANTEES ARE ASKED TO FURNISH INFORMATION IN ORDER TO ENABLE THE FOUNDATION TO DETERMINE WHETHER THEY HAVE RECEIVED A DETERMINATION OF 501(C)(3) STATUS FROM THE U.S. INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE OR MAY BE CONSIDERED THE EQUIVALENT OF A TAX-EXEMPT CHARITY, IF FORMED OUTSIDE THE UNITED STATES. PROSPECTIVE GRANTEES WITH RESPECT TO WHOM THE FOUNDATION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE "EXPENDITURE RESPONSIBILITY" OBLIGATIONS ARE INFORMED BY LETTER, BEFORE PAYMENT IS MADE ON A GRANT, OF THE RESPONSIBILITIES IMPOSED UPON THE FOUNDATION AND ITS GRANTEES BY THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1986, AS AMENDED. EACH GRANTEE MUST AGREE IN WRITING TO THOSE TERMS AND CONDITIONS, INCLUDING THE OBLIGATION TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL AND SUBSTANTIVE REPORTS ON HOW FOUNDATION GRANT FUNDS ARE EXPENDED. THE REPORTS THAT ARE RECEIVED ARE REVIEWED FOR GENERAL ACCURACY, SUFFICIENCY AND COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE GRANT. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION IS REQUESTED FROM GRANTEES IN INSTANCES WHERE REPORTS ARE CONSIDERED INADEQUATE. WHERE THE FOUNDATION HAS NOT RECEIVED FINANCIAL OR SUBSTANTIVE REPORTS FROM A GRANTEE WHEN EXPECTED, FOUNDATION STAFF FOLLOW UP IN SEVERAL WAYS, INCLUDING REMINDERS THAT ARE SENT AT MONTHLY INTERVALS AFTER REPORTS ARE EXPECTED AND PERSONAL FOLLOW-UP BY PROGRAM AND GRANTS MANAGEMENT STAFF THROUGH TELEPHONE, MAIL AND E-MAIL.STATEMENT 20 LISTS GRANT AND PROGRAM-RELATED INVESTMENT EXPENDITURES WITH RESPECT TO WHICH THE FOUNDATION HAS EXERCISED EXPENDITURE RESPONSIBILITY. WHERE THE GRANTEE'S NAME IS FOLLOWED BY AN ASTERISK (*), THE GRANTEE ORGANIZATION IS EITHER A PRIVATE FOUNDATION, A PRIVATE OPERATING FOUNDATION, OR A FOREIGN PRIVATE-FOUNDATION EQUIVALENT. ALL OTHER GRANTEES ARE NON-501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS OR ORGANIZATIONS FOR WHICH THE FOUNDATION HAS NOT MADE A REASONABLE DETERMINATION OF 501(C)(3) EQUIVALENCY STATUS THAT RECEIVED GRANTS FOR CHARITABLE PROJECTS AND MAINTAINED PAYMENTS IN SEGREGATED FUNDS AS REQUIRED BY TREASURY REG. 53.4945-6(C).IF A PARTICULAR GRANT EXPENDITURE IS SHOWN TO HAVE BEEN FULLY EXPENDED BY THE GRANTEE BUT THE FOUNDATION HAS NOT YET RECEIVED ONE OR MORE NARRATIVE REPORTS, THE FOUNDATION WILL REPORT ON THE STATUS OF THE EXPENDITURE ON OUR 2018 990-PF. UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED, THE REPORTS RECEIVED WERE FOUND TO BE IN ORDER AND TO SHOW THAT THE FUNDS WERE FULLY EXPENDED FOR THE PURPOSE OF THE GRANT.REPORTING STATUS IS AS OF 10/18/19.

WITH REGARD TO PART XV SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION REFLECTING GRANTS AND CONTRIBUTIONS PAID DURING THE YEAR AND APPROVED FOR FUTURE PAYMENT, ORGANIZATIONS GIVEN THE FOUNDATION STATUS CODE DESIGNATION "PC" (OR PUBLIC CHARITY) INCLUDE U.S. PUBLIC CHARITIES DESCRIBED IN SECTION 509(A)(1) OR (2) OF THE CODE AND ORGANIZATIONS BASED OUTSIDE THE U.S. THAT HAVE BEEN FOUND TO BE THE EQUIVALENT OF A U.S. PUBLIC CHARITY.

THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATIONBELLAGIO CENTER, ITALYSUMMARY OF DIRECT CHARITABLE ACTIVITESFORM 990PF, PART IX-ATHE BELLAGIO CENTER HAD OPERATING EXPENSES OF $5,658,878. SINCE 1959, THE CENTER HAS SERVED AS A RESOURCE FOR FOSTERING DIALOGUE AND PROBLEM SOLVING FOR DIVERSE PARTICIPANTS AROUND THE WORLD. THE CENTER HOSTS CONFERENCES THAT FOCUS ON TOPICS OF INTERNATIONAL INTEREST, WITH PREFERENCE GIVEN TO APPLICANTS WHO PROMOTE DEVELOPMENT AND ALIGN WITH THE FOUNDATION'S AREAS OF INTEREST. IN 2018 THE BELLAGIO CENTER HOSTED 46 MEETINGS WITH A TOTAL OF 1,106 PARTICIPANTS; 36% OF WHOM WERE FROM THE UNITED STATES, 33% FROM DEVELOPED COUNTRIES OUTSIDE OF UNITED STATES, AND 31% FROM DEVELOPING COUNTRIES. IN ADDITION, THE CENTER OFFERS TWO-TO-FOUR WEEK RESIDENCIES TO SCHOLARS, ARTISTS, AND PRACTITIONERS. IN 2018, THE CENTER HOSTED 109 RESIDENTS, 44% OF WHOM WERE FROM THE UNITED STATES, 25% FROM DEVELOPED COUNTRIES OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES, AND 31% FROM DEVELOPING COUNTRIES.
